tutorial.title: Navigation Bar Variations
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use CSS Flexbox Grow, Shrink, Basis, and shorthand notation to create several navbar variations for a client

executableContent.instructions:
A small business owner has asked for your help to create a website. They want two versions for a navigation bar so you'll build two options.

First, let's inspect the HTML document and the stylesheet.  We've also included a blank stylesheet for you to build in this exercise, `index.css`.  This is where you'll write all your CSS code. Do **not** modify any of the other files.

We have added some functionality in the JavaScript file `index.js` to change the option for the navbar, but you can ignore it for now. You'll learn JS in the future!

As we mentioned, in this project, you'll create a website for a bakery owner. You'll create two navigation bar options (with CSS classes `.one` and `.two` ) and organize the body using Flexbox.  

First, let's add the CSS class `.navbar` to your stylesheet, and make it a Flexbox container.

1. Apply the appropriate `display` property to turn the `.navbar` element into a Flexbox container.

files.name: style.css
index.js

executableContent.instructions:
The navigation bar contains email and phone icons, a link to the home page, and a search bar. 

For the first option:
 - the email and phone icons will be the same size,
 - the `Home` link will be twice as big as the icons,
 - the search bar will be three times as big as the icons. 

First, let's tackle the `.mail` and `.phone` elements. You can find them inside the `.one` class in the HTML file.

Since we want to set the size of each option's email and phone icons separately, let's create specific selectors for the icons in option 1 by including their classes next to the `.one` selector:
```
.one .mail {

}
```
1. Create a first css rule to select the `.mail` element inside the `.one` div element. Just like the example provided.

2. Create a second css rule to select the `.phone` element inside the `.one` div element. Just as you have created the `.one .mail`.

3. Apply the appropriate flex property to the first option's `.mail` and `.phone` div elements, so they can grow by `1`.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Note that adding two classes separated by a space in a css rule will select the element with the second class that is a child from the element with the first class.

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's tackle the first option's `Home` link and search bar. The `Home` link should be able to expand to take up to twice as much space as the `.phone` and `.icon` containers.

1. Add the appropriate `flex` property to the `.one .home` CSS class, so that it can take up to twice as much space as the icon elements.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Remember to use the flex-grow property with a value of `2 ` to make one element take up twice as much space as another element.

executableContent.instructions:
The search bar should be able to expand up to three times bigger than the icon elements. 

Let's make that happen. When finished, play with the window size to see your navigation bar size dynamically!

1. Add the appropriate `flex` property to the `.one .search` CSS class so that it can expand up to three times bigger than the icon elements.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Remember to use a flex-grow value of  3 to expand an element up to three times bigger than another element.

executableContent.instructions:
Great work on the first navigation bar option! Let's move on to the second navigation bar option. 

For this design, the search bar should always be `100px` wide and the `Home` link should expand up to four times more than the search bar because it's more important.

1. Add the appropriate `flex` property to the `.two .home` CSS element, so it can grow up to four times the size of the `.search` element (which we'll work on next).
2. Then, run your code and use the dropdown to select the second navigation bar option to see your changes.

executableContent.instructions:
We need the search bar to always be `100px` wide and not grow or shrink. 

1. Set the `flex-grow` and `flex-shrink` properties so that the `.two .search` `CSS` element does not grow or shrink. 
2. Then, set the appropriate `flex` property so that the search bar is `100px` wide by default.  
3. Finally, run your code and use the dropdown to select the second navigation bar option to see your changes.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's clean up our syntax with the help of the `flex` shorthand.

1. Convert your CSS rules for the `.search` CSS class to shorthand `flex` syntax. 
2. Then, run your code and use the dropdown to select the second navigation bar option to see your changes.

executableContent.instructions:
The phone and mail icons are a little too close together in the second option, so let's tell Flexbox which default width to assign. We'll start with the phone icon.

1. Add the appropriate `flex` property to the second navigation bar option's phone icon so that its default width is `50px`.
2. Remember to run your code and click "option 2" in the dropdown to be able to see your changes.

Finally, let's assign a default width for the mail icon. When finished, play with the window width to see your navigation bars dynamically scale.

1. Add the appropriate `flex` property to the second navigation bar option's mail icon so that its default width is `50px`.
